questions.text: Which of the following does not distinguish psoriasis from other arthropathies?
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea is not a typical symptom that distinguishes psoriasis from other types of arthropathies.

Psoriatic arthritis is a chronic inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis

Clinical features of psoriatic arthritis are described in terms of articular and extra-articular manifestations.

Articular/Periarticular Manifestations of Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Arthritis presents in an oligoarticular vs polyarticular pattern
  • Enthesitis (inflammation around the insertion of ligaments, tendons, or joint capsules),
  • Dactylitis (swelling of the entire digit, finger, or toe, "sausage digit")
  • Tenosynovitis
  • Axial disease involving sacroiliac joints, usually asymmetric
  • Spondylitis

Extra-Articular Manifestations of Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Psoriatic skin disease
  • Nail disease: Onycholysis, pitting, and splinter hemorrhages.
  • Ocular disease in the form of uveitis

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Dactylitis (Incorrect)

  • A hallmark feature of psoriatic arthritis, often called "sausage digit."
  • Caused by diffuse inflammation of the tendon sheaths, synovium, and soft tissues of the entire finger or toe.
  • Less common in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and other inflammatory arthritides.

Choice C: Enthesitis (Incorrect)

  • Inflammation of tendon and ligament insertions (e.g., Achilles tendon, plantar fascia).
  • A characteristic feature of spondyloarthropathies, including PsA.
  • Can help differentiate PsA from RA, which typically lacks enthesitis.

Choice D: Nail Pitting (Incorrect)

  • Strongly associated with psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis.
  • Caused by abnormal keratinization in the nail matrix.
  • Other nail changes: onycholysis, hyperkeratosis, and splinter hemorrhages.

Key Takeaway:

Diarrhea is not a distinguishing feature of psoriatic arthritis, whereas dactylitis, enthesitis, and nail pitting are characteristic findings.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a great toenail infection has significant discolouration with subungual hyperkeratosis, which has produced surface changes. She is suspected to be having onychomycosis. Which is the topical drug given in toenail onychomycosis?
questions.solution:
• Choice B. Tavaborole is a topical antifungal medication specifically indicated for the treatment of toenail onychomycosis. It works by inhibiting fungal protein synthesis. Tavaborole is applied directly to the affected toenail.

It is an approved topical agent for treating mild to moderate onychomycosis.

It targets Leucyl tRNA synthesis, thus inhibiting fungal protein synthesis lead to fungal cell death.

Topical agent for onychomycosis:

  • Amorolfine nail lacquer 5%
  • Ciclopirox olamine nail lacquer 8%
  • Tavaborole 5%
  • Effinaconazole 10%

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • Choice A. Itraconazole is an oral antifungal medication used to treat various fungal infections, including onychomycosis. While it is effective in treating toenail and fingernail infections, it is not a topical treatment.
  • Choice C. Griseofulvin is an oral antifungal agent that is used to treat superficial fungal infections, including onychomycosis. However, it is not a topical treatment.
  • Choice D. Caspofungin is an intravenous antifungal used primarily for systemic fungal infections, particularly invasive aspergillosis or candidiasis. It is not indicated for the treatment of onychomycosis and is not a topical antifungal treatment.

Key Takeaway:

Tavaborole is a topical antifungal specifically approved for the treatment of toenail onychomycosis, making it the correct choice in this case. The other options are systemic treatments and not typically used as topical solutions for nail infections.

questions.text: A gardener who is a resident of the sub-Himalayan belt presents with painless subcutaneous nodules and shallow ulcers on the arm. Axillary lymph nodes are enlarged. Aspirate from the lymph nodes shows elongated yeasts that are 3-5 microns. Culture on fungal medium was done. The image of the colony isolated at 22°C, LPCB mount is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, which is typically associated with gardeners and individuals who have frequent contact with soil or plant material, as it is a soil-borne fungus.

This fungus is often introduced through puncture wounds (e.g., from a thorn prick) and causes a characteristic lymphocutaneous infection, where the lesion spreads linearly along the lymphatic channels.

The presentation of painless subcutaneous nodules, shallow ulcers, and enlarged lymph nodes, often with a chronic progression, is characteristic of this infection.

The characteristic yeast form of Sporothrix schenckii (elongated yeasts, 3-5 microns) seen in lymph node aspirates, as well as the fungal culture growing at 22°C, supports the diagnosis of sporotrichosis.

Asteroid bodies are large, star-shaped structures seen in the cytoplasm of macrophages in tissue sections infected with Sporothrix schenckii.

Asteroid bodies are the histopathological hallmark of Sporotrichosis.

Incorrect choice explanations:

  • Choice B. Chromoblastomycosis
    Caused by dematiaceous (dark-pigmented) fungi, leading to verrucous lesions and often a more warty, raised appearance of the skin. It is typically seen in individuals who have prolonged exposure to soil or wood,

In chromoblastomycosis, the infection is caused by pigmented fungi like Fonsecaea and Cladophialophora, which produce characteristic brownish, copper-colored sclerotic bodies

  • Choice C. Coccidiomycosis
    Caused by Coccidioides species and is typically found in dry, desert regions like the southwestern United States and parts of Central and South America, not specifically in sub-Himalayan regions. It primarily affects the lungs and can cause systemic disease but Coccidioides forms arthroconidia and spherules in tissue, not elongated yeasts.
  • Choice D. Histoplasmosis
    Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, which is often found in bat guano and bird droppings.

The infection typically presents with pulmonary symptoms, though it can also disseminate to other organs. It can cause granulomatous lesions, but it does not typically present with the skin nodules and lymphadenopathy seen in this case.

Key Takeaway:

The likely diagnosis is Sporotrichosis due to the subcutaneous nodules, ulcers, and lymphadenopathy, combined with the microscopic and culture findings of elongated yeasts. This matches the typical presentation of a fungal infection from Sporothrix schenckii, which is common in individuals who work with plants or soil, like gardeners.

questions.text: Which of the following is transmitted by bare feet in the soil?
questions.solution:
Madurella mycetomatis is a soil-borne fungus that causes eumycetoma, a chronic, subcutaneous fungal infection.

It is typically contracted when a person walks barefoot over contaminated soil, especially in tropical and subtropical regions.

The infection often presents as a swelling or mass with draining sinuses and is caused by direct trauma to the skin. Therefore, it is transmitted through direct contact with contaminated soil, making it the correct answer.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B. Curvularia is found in soil and decaying plant matter, but it is generally not transmitted by walking barefoot in soil. It is more often associated with respiratory infections in immunocompromised individuals or corneal infections in certain circumstances.

Choice C. Nocardia brasiliensis is a bacterium, not a fungus, and is known to cause infections in immunocompromised individuals. It can cause mycetoma, a disease similar to eumycetoma caused by fungi, but it is transmitted through cuts or abrasions in the skin (not primarily through bare feet in soil). Nocardia infections are typically acquired through soil or environmental exposure.

Choice D. Aspergillus fumigatus is a ubiquitous mold that can be found in soil, decaying organic matter, and other environments. However, it typically causes infections when spores are inhaled, especially in immunocompromised individuals. Respiratory infection from Aspergillus is more common than skin infection.

Key Takeaway:

The correct answer is Madurella mycetomatis, as it is a fungus that is specifically transmitted through bare feet in the soil, causing a type of fungal infection called eumycetoma. The other options are associated with different transmission routes or conditions.

questions.text: Which organism is not associated with urethritis in men?
questions.solution:
Choice B: Gardnerella vaginalis is primarily associated with bacterial vaginosis in women, not urethritis in men. Although it can be present in the male urethra, it is not typically a cause of urethritis in men. It is not considered a primary pathogen for urethral infection in men, making it the correct answer.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice A: Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonorrhea, which commonly presents as urethritis in men. It is one of the primary causes of urethral infections and can lead to symptoms such as painful urination and discharge.

Choice C. Mycoplasma genitalium is a bacterium that can cause urethritis in both men and women. It has been identified as a significant cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) in men, contributing to symptoms such as painful urination and discharge.

Choice D. Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that can cause urethritis in both men and women. In men, it often results in non-gonococcal urethritis, although it can also be asymptomatic.

Key Takeaway:

Gardnerella vaginalis is not typically associated with urethritis in men, unlike the other organisms listed, which are more commonly linked to urethral infections.

questions.text: A woman presents with a foul-smelling discharge; examination of the cervix is normal. A whiff test is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by an imbalance in the vaginal flora, where normal lactobacilli are replaced by overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria.

Amsel's criteria:

There are four parameters used to determine the presence or absence of BV. These are:

  • Thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge
  • Clue cells on wet mount microscopy
  • a vaginal fluid pH of over 4.5 when placing the discharge on litmus paper
  • Release fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution to wet mount - also known as "whiff test."

Three of the four above criteria must be present to confirm the diagnosis,

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • Choice B. Candidiasis typically causes thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge that may be itchy but usually does not have a foul odor.

Common in diabetics and immunocompromised patients.

  • Choice C. Chlamydial is a bacterial infection that can cause cervicitis and urethritis, but it often presents with little to no symptoms or with mild symptoms such as a mucopurulent discharge.

A laboratory test (NAAT) would be needed for diagnosis.

  • Choice D. Trichomoniasis is caused by a protozoan parasite, Trichomonas vaginalis. It may cause a frothy, yellow-green discharge with a foul odor. The cervix is inflamed and has punctate hemorrhages, a condition often called 'strawberry cervix,' or colpitis macularis.

Trichomoniasis can be diagnosed with wet mount microscopy or culture.

Key Takeaway:

The presence of a foul-smelling discharge, a normal cervix, and a positive whiff test are classic signs of bacterial vaginosis. This condition is characterized by an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria, leading to the typical fishy odor that is detected during the whiff test.

choices.text: Ulcers are seen over dorsum of the penis
More associated with Crohn's disease than ulcerative colitis

questions.text: Which of the following is false pertaining to Behcet's disease?
questions.solution:
Choice B. Ulcers are seen over dorsum of the penis
This statement is false.

In Behcet's disease, genital ulcers typically appear on the scrotum or the glans penis (not the dorsum of the penis). These ulcers are painful and recurrent, but they are not typically localized to the dorsum of the penis, making this the incorrect statement.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A. Bilateral panuveitis
Behcet's disease commonly involves inflammation of the uveal tract (uveitis), and it can cause panuveitis (inflammation of the entire uveal tract) in both eyes. This can be bilateral, affecting both eyes, and is one of the classic manifestations of Behcet's disease.

Choice C. More associated with Crohn's disease than ulcerative colitis
Behcet's disease has a higher association with Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis. Both conditions are inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), but Behcet's is more frequently linked with Crohn's disease. This statement is true.

Choice D. Pathergy test is positive
The pathergy test is a diagnostic test used to help identify Behcet's disease. A positive result occurs when a sterile needle is inserted into the skin, and a papule or pustule forms at the site within 24-48 hours.

Key Takeaway:

The false statement is B, as genital ulcers in Behcet's disease are more commonly seen on the scrotum or glans penis, not the dorsum of the penis. The other statements regarding panuveitis, the association with Crohn's disease, and the pathergy test are accurate in the context of Behcet's disease.
